text: A machete slashes INTO FRAME.  An American in battered fedora and leather jacket, accompanied by two gunbearers, hacks his way through dense bush.  We see him from the ba only.  He hacks an opening, bats fly out AT CAMERA and th bushes part, revealing huge overgrown stone letters -- th Mayan ruin look -- that spell "AIRPLANE II."
The Jupiter shuttle stands ready to fly.
of Houston Control with appropriate jargon V.O.
of a crowded modern terminal.
All lunar departures, please proceed to concourse lounge 'B.'
of heavy traffic at LAX.
A number of men in futuristic-looking mining outfits, carrying futuristic gear, unload a truck with a corporate logo that reads:  TRX DEEP SPACE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.
Attention, all Pulsar Four mining personnel.
The miners look up.
Please report to the Resource Expeditions office, level seven.

Two miners head to terminal doors and pass FOUR NUNS, who bid farewell to FATHER O'FLANAGAN.  O'Flanagan shakes the hands of the first three elderly nuns, then grabs the las young gorgeous nun and kisses her passionately.
No tongues, Father.
A group tour moves through the room behind controllers.
All lunar shuttle landings are handled by these computers and simulated on these video units.
(at computer screen) You're programmed on R-two-niner and locked, Lunar eight six.  Over.
Three crew members watch the lit landing strip as their shuttle approaches.
(to co-pilot) It's out of our hands now, gentlemen.
They smile.
The CONTROLLER moves away from his video unit.  A kid fro the tour who has lagged behind hits a switch.  The screen turns into a video game with SFX.  He flips knobs.
The crew are tossed from side to side and try to regain control of the ship.
The Lunar shuttle careens towards the terminal, out of control.

The kid is still playing like mad.  A flash appears on th screen.  SFX VIDEO GAME EXPLOSION and a corresponding EXPLOSION from outside.  SIRENS WAIL.  CONTROLLERS run around.  The kid is oblivious and walks away.
BUD KRUGER, head of the space center, and the COMMISSIONE get out of a limo under a sign that reads, "MERCURY SHUTTLE."  They walk and talk.
Commissioner, we both know the Mercury shuttle needs another month of pre-launch testing.
Forget it.  The boys on the board want that shuttle to go on schedule.
Kruger and the Commissioner go up escalator.
And what do the boys on the board know about safety, Commissioner?  Let me talk to them.
Bud, get wise to the political realities. The boys on the board are under a lot of pressure from the boys downtown.
Kruger gets a pack of cigarettes from a machine. Commissioner buys a newspaper.
And I'll be the one they'll hang if there's a screw-up.

Kruger and Commissioner get shoes shined.  A MAN next to them in white shoes reads paper with headline -- "SOLAR PLANT MELTDOWN, 500 WORKERS SERIOUSLY TANNED" -- and does notice his shoes are getting black polish.
Listen, Bud, the boys downtown are under heavy fire from the boys in Washington. That's why they're putting pressure on the boys on the board.
Kruger and Commissioner head down escalator.
Well, you tell the boys on the board to tell the boys downtown to let the boys in Washington know that the press has been nosing around my people in the front office.
Kruger and Commissioner head to their limo.
You handle your front office people, I'll handle the press and leave the boys in Washington to the boys downtown and the boys downtown to the boys on the board.
Commissioner.
They stop and look at each other.
What?
I just wish it was that simple.
They get back in their limo and drive off.
(over P.A.) This is Mercury One control.  We have condition green.  Mark launch 'T' minus two hours and counting.  I repeat, we have condition green.
Dressed as a doctor and looking in a Controller's mouth. The Controller's face is bright green.
This condition isn't as bad as it could be if it were a lot worse.  Take these pills. (hands him pills and water) Here's some water.
What is it, doctor?
Two parts oxygen, one part hydrogen. It'll make the pills go down easier.
WIDE ANGLE LENS PANS the under-belly past the nose as if viewer bent his head back as far as he could, until... th CAMERA crashes to the ground as if it has fallen off the tripod.

PAN workers on scaffolding who check gauges on exterior o ship.  PAN to panel that reads, "SOLID FUEL CHUTE" -- a sweaty muscular worker in undershirt opens the panel, fla shoot out.  LOOSEN to reveal another sweaty worker in undershirt shoveling coal into the chute.  PAN to other workers checking more gauges.  SUDDENLY a PANEL EXPLODES. Smoking, sparking wires pop out.  A WORKER runs up with walkie-talkie in hand.
(into walkie-talkie) This is Mercury station six!  Get me the Sarg and fast!

SIMON KURTZ and ELAINE THOMPSON get out of a taxi with ha luggage.  They are dressed in matching flight outfits. A JAPANESE COUPLE get out of a taxi -- the man has about fifty cameras around his neck.  His wife hangs another camera on him.  He crashes to the ground under the weight Simon and Elaine are approached by a BUSINESSMAN with handful of roses.
Would you like to buy a rose to help bail out Chrysler?  We're an all-profit organization and need all the money we can get.
Simon hands the Businessman a dollar and takes a rose.
(to Businessman) Here.
The Businessman joins six other BUSINESSMEN carrying sign with LEE IACCOCA's picture.  They all smile and chant.
(to Hari Krishna) IACCOCA, IACCOCA, IACCOCA, IARAMA.
Simon hands Elaine the rose.  She takes his arm as they w towards the sign that reads, "MERCURY SHUTTLE."
For the best little computer officer on the Mercury mission.
(smiling) Simon.
Who would believe that Elaine Thompson was once a stewardess on the Denver-Chicago run.
And I can hardly believe that I'm engaged to someone like you, Simon.  I'm a very lucky woman.
A man with a suitcase on a leash walks beside them.  The case pulls him along like a dog and takes a leak on a pos
Women and the space program have come a long way, sweetheart.  But after the wedding, no more complicated computers for my little girl.
But, darling, they've offered me a chance to head up the computer analysis division for the Jupiter probe.
You're heading up the division in charge of babies for Mr. and Mrs. Simon Kurtz.
He kisses Elaine and smiles.
And that's an order, Lieutenant.
The man with the case on a leash passes a woman with a ca on a leash.  The cases start a violent, BARKING DOG FIGHT

SARG (imagine George Kennedy), dressed in a tuxedo, tie undone, with a huge cigar, which he eats during the conversation, talks to his wife on his car phone.  A work in hard hat waits next to him.  Behind the worker are fue drums and a large sign that reads:  DANGER, FUEL -- ABSOLUTELY NO SMOKING, ABSOLUTELY NO SPITTING.
(on car phone) Marge, you better go without me.  We've got a condition red.

head_text.subj: SPLIT SCREEN WITH WIFE AT HOME.

text: (in evening gown, a cigar stuck in her mouth) We've got a condition red with our marriage.  I think you're in love with that shuttle, not with me.  I want a divorce, Sarg.
Sarg lights his cigar.
Is there someone else, Marge?  Is that it?
Sarg throws the lit match towards the "ABSOLUTELY NO SMOKING" sign.  The worker grimaces but nothing happens.
Sarg, there's been someone else for fifteen years.  You were just too involved in your work to see it.

They hang up.  Sarg bites off the end of his cigar and sp it in the direction of the "NO SPITTING" sign, blowing th worker OUT OF FRAME with a MASSIVE EXPLOSION.  Sarg hops into his car, takes a Lava lamp from the seat and puts it the car roof -- like Kojak's flasher.  The lamp flashes, SIREN WAILS, as Sarg pulls away.

He thinks about his wife.  SPLIT SCREEN FLASHBACK OF THEI BEDROOM.  Marge, a cigar in her mouth, is in bed with fiv football players -- other half-clad athletes (hockey, baseball, wrestling, basketball) line up for their turn a her.  Sarg has to climb over them to kiss her goodbye.
Don't wait up for me, sweetheart.  We're testing the retro-rockets tonight.
You just can't see it, can you, Sarg.
We'll talk tomorrow, hon.  I promise.
The WILSON FAMILY -- JOHN, ALICE and ten-year-old JIMMY - carry luggage.  Jimmy carries a puppy in a small cage.
All Mercury passengers please proceed to passenger processing, concourse level 'C.'
That's us.
Jimmy Wilson looks at Scraps.
Will Scraps be able to sit with us, Dad?
We'll have to check, Jimmy.  It's a pretty long trip to Mercury.
A PORTER approaches.
Can I help you folks?
(handing him a bag) Thanks.
(noticing Scraps) Is that your puppy, son?
Yeah, his name is Scraps and he's going to Mercury with us.
No dogs are allowed on the shuttle, son.
But they said...
(pulling out a handgun) Scraps will have to be shot.  I can do it for you here if you like.
He SHOOTS.
Scraps!!!
(laughing) Just joking.  Blanks.  See, Scraps is fine.
Alice, John, and Porter crack up while Jimmy cries.
It was just a joke, Jimmy.
Alice and John look at each other as if there is somethin wrong with their son.
A man lifts a large dog cage out of the trunk of a taxi. Inside is another man dressed in S&M leathers.
(to Man in Cage) If we can't fit you under the seat, you'll just have to be locked up with the luggage.
The man in the cage seems to relish the latter suggestion Two Porters lift the cage onto a conveyor belt next to Jimmy's dog.
Sarg stands beside the burnt panel on the side of the shuttle.  He is eating another cigar, holding a burnt wir and talking into a walkie-talkie.
There's no way this wiring could have passed inspection without Simon Kurtz's okay!

head_text.subj: SPLIT SCREEN OF KRUGER IN HIS OFFICE

text: (on phone) Just patch up the damage and get that ship ready to fly.  That's an order, mister!
You've got it, mister.  But you can tell your boys on the board for me that this thing stinks to high heaven of kickback.

Kruger turns to room.  LOOSEN to reveal a dozen five-year old boys in three-piece suits, smoking cigars.  A huge Keans-style painting of three astronauts with big eyes, painted on black velvet, hangs in b.g.
You heard it, boys.  Now, what do you say?
Fuck him!
Sarg looks at the wire and shakes his head.
(to worker) Ted Striker was right six months ago when he test-piloted this sucker.  And what did he get for telling the truth?  A one-way ticket to Palukaville.
Sarg spits a chunk of cigar on the ground, blowing the worker OUT OF FRAME with a MASSIVE EXPLOSION.
A jet fighter streaks across the sky.

TED STRIKER is at the controls.  His oxygen mask hangs lo from his helmet.  Clouds outside shoot by -- he's going a least 700 MPH.  A bird lands on the nose in front of the window.  Ted shoos it away by knocking on the glass.  He takes a slug of beer and cockily pulls on the stick.
The plane does a barrel roll.
Ted has beer all over his face and shirt.
Striker's fighter comes in for a landing.
CLOSEUP of sign, "WELCOME TO RIO MONTENEGRO -- POP.

COME UP on CLOSEUP of parachute.  PAN past a flight jacke thrown over a chair, clothes strewn around, a framed phot of TED and ELAINE on the bedtable next to a bottle of whiskey.  The room is hot and dusty.  Ted lies on the bed soaked with sweat, a drink in his hand, a cigarette dangl from his lip.  He takes a drink and, forgetting to remove the cigarette, swallows it without batting an eye.  LOOSE to find a CRUCIFIX above the bed with a real person on it
(to self) Who could have figured it would come to this.  It'll be twenty years this week that I lost my entire squadron over Macho Grande.  Planes, too.
You're too low, Striker!  You're too low!
The Crucifix in b.g. looks around trying to figure out wh the planes in the SUPER are coming from.
After the war, I couldn't go near anything with a pair of wings.
A pigeon lands on the Cross.
That is, until fate dropped me on the seat of my pants at the stick of a 167 into Chicago with no crew.
It's funny how fate can make heroes out of cowards.
The Crucifix gives a look of exasperated boredom. SUPER:  NEW YORK TIMES HEADLINE, "STRIKER SAVES l20!" OVE PHOTO OF TED AND ELAINE WAVING.
Then came the job offers.

head_text.subj: POSTS" OVER A PHOTO OF TED AND ELAINE WAVING.

text: The publicity.
Even the key to the City of New York.
Now look at me.
Ted wipes the sweat off his face and switches on the tabl fan.  A tornado force wind destroys the room as he fights switch off the fan.
A peasant boy takes a newspaper from a newsstand.  The headline reads, "MERCURY SHUTTLE FLIES TOMORROW."
Senor Ted!

The boy hightails it through the town-square and passes: -- A large alabaster statue of the Generalissimo snorting cocaine. -- Soldiers dragging nuns off screaming. -- Nuns dragging soldiers off screaming. He passes a line of peasants held at gunpoint by soldiers We HOLD on them.  In b.g. are stores like HITLER'S SHOES,

head_text.subj: TRIEU GUYS FROM SAIGON LIQUORS, KEY'S KEYS

text: stands in doorway.
(to first peasant) Traficante de drugas o communista?
SUPER:  SUBTITLES -- "Drug dealer or communist?"
(pleading) Traficante de drugas, traficante de drugas!
SUPER:  SUBTITLES -- "Drug dealer, drug dealer!" The soldier lets the peasant go.
(to second peasant) Traficante de drugas o communista?
SUPER:  SUBTITLES -- "Drug dealer or communist?" The peasant panics and bolts from the line.  The soldiers FIRE.
Communista!
He runs up to THE HOTEL MONTENEGRO.  A sign reads, "TV, POOL, WATERBEDS, DONKEY, KLEENEX" -- All but "KLEENEX" ar crossed out.  He runs inside.
A clean-cut AMERICAN COUPLE argue with Desk Clerk.
(to Desk Clerk) We've lost all our travelers' checks!
What are we going to do?!
Calm down.  What kind were they?
American Excess!
The Clerk throws up his hands and strikes the same pose a the Karl Marden look-alike in the "AMERICAN EXCESS" poste b.g.
I'd say you're fucked.
The boy passes them and bounds up the stairs.
CLOSEUP of Ted pacing.
(to self) Next thing I know, I'm the chief test pilot for the XR-2300, NASA's first Mercury shuttle.  That is, until I report she's got more flaws than the Titanic.
LOOSEN slowly to find the Cross empty and the man who was it hanging, his feet dangling next to Ted.
Now I'm testing old F-l8s for some crazy Generalissimo who thinks there's a commie behind every tree in the Amazon.
SUDDENLY the boy bursts in.
Senor Ted!  Look!
Ted spins and the paper stays still.  He stops.
My God!  They're launching the ZR-2300. Do you know what that is, Jose?
The muffler bracket for a '78 Pinto.
No, that's an XR-2200.  The XR-2300 is the Mercury shuttle.  They can't do it!
Ted races out.
Taxi!
Ted jumps into the taxi on bottom of pile.  The driver POUNDS on his HORN -- it CONTINUES TO BLARE as they pull away, dragging other taxis.
Houston, Texas.
Houston, Texas, senor??
Right at the corner, left at the light. Here's a map and step on it!
Ted throws a map onto the floor of the front seat.  The driver steps on the map.
An old truck loaded high with furniture pulls up.  A YOUN MAN and his PARENTS, looking like the family from THE GRA OF WRATH, get out.
We finally made it, Ma.  Mercury.  We're gonna start all over agin.  A whole new life.
Where the soil is rich.
He bends down and takes a handful of earth from the termi sidewalk and lets it run through his fingers.
And the union strong.  Where men are free to realize their true potential.
A black PORTER approaches and grabs a bag at the bottom o their pile of junk.
Can I help you?
Where black men and white men, working together, can move mountains.
The Porter pulls the bag and the entire mountain of junk cascades to the ground.

It is covered in mud, flames shoot out from under the hoo the HORN BLARES.  The driver flips off the meter which reads, "874,567,004,500,000,000."  The numbers run off th meter along a special attachment.
That'll be eight hundred and seventy-four zillion quastavitas.
Here's three bucks.  Keep the change.
Thank you!!
STELLA BARRINGTON pushes her wheelchair-ridden father, DR CYRUS BARRINGTON, through the terminal crowd.  A PORTER approaches.
You folks need any help?
Thanks, but we have a terrific woman in on Thursdays.
Say, isn't that Dr. Barrington, the world- renowned agronomist?
Yes.
It's a privilege to meet you, sir, I'm familiar with all your work.
Let's go, Daddy.  We have to check in. (to Porter) He was never appreciated at the Institute.
Ah, yes, the Institute, I'm familiar with it.
Now he's D-Y-I-N-Ging and wants to be buried on Mercury.
Stella pushes her father away as another PORTER approache our first Porter.
Say, wasn't that Dr. Barrington, the world-renowned agronomist?
That's right.  Are you familiar with his work?
No, but the missus sure is.
The departures side reads.  "MERCURY SHUTTLE - DEPARTS 6:
(to self) I have to stop that flight.
Ted pushes his way through the crowd past two businessmen HOLD on them as BUSINESSMAN 1 straightens BUSINESSMAN 2's tie and hair.
Don't worry about the Viatex account. It's a buy-sell option.  We can't get hurt in either case.
Just keep on top of their legal people, Bob.
Don't sweat it.
They kiss and part.
(to traveller) We can take your in-flight dinner orders here, if you like.  Today there's lobster or rack of lamb.
The lobster sounds nice.
The Agent throws a huge lobster into a steaming cauldron. SFX:  LOBSTER SCREAM.
(rushing up) Where can I find mission control?
(without pointing or indicating in any way) Information's over there.
Thanks.
He seems a bit puzzled but moves on.
Ted passes travellers in rags.
(to traveller in rags) Today there's the swill or the slop.
The slop sounds nice.

Ted passes the "NO CLASS" line.  Travellers in line all w gaudy double-knit suits, white belts and shoes, carry lav lamps and bongo drums, wear alpine hats, etc.  The agent hands a NO CLASS traveller his ticket with large foam dic dangling.  Ted spots the INFORMATION counter and heads fo it.
(to Info Agent) What's the fastest animal on earth?
The cheetah.  Next.
Should I fake my orgasms?
Yes.  Next.
Next in line are three armed, bearded "TERRORISTS."
Please, where is flight to Miami?
(without indicating anything) Over there.  Next.
The TERRORISTS leave looking confused.
Mission control?
(without indicating anything) It's over therrrrrrr!
The agent is shot with an arrow and slumps over the count
He looks in the CAMERA. MUSIC:  DRAMATIC STING.
That's strange.  I just came from over there.
Elaine, Simon, and FRANK MORGAN, the shuttle pilot, talk.
I'll meet you on board.  I've got some business to attend to.
Frank leaves.
(to Elaine) Frank's the best pilot in the program.
I'm so excited, Simon.
I guess this is a first for you.
No, I've been excited before.
Elaine.
(turning around) Te...!
That's not important now, Elaine.  We have to talk.
Simon pulls Elaine away.  They all walk and talk.
Ted, we've been worried sick ever since you escaped from the Ronald Reagan Institute For The Mentally Feeble.
They walk faster.  The b.g. starts whipping by as if they running.  Wind blows in their hair.
Are you on the Mercury mission?
That's right, Striker.  And we're getting married when we return.
The b.g. moves faster.  The wind gets stronger.  They pas marathon refreshment stand and are handed wet sponges and cups of Gatoraid.
It's got to be stopped!
But, Ted, the invitations have already gone out.
I mean the Mercury flight.  It's not safe and, Kurtz, you know why.
You're still crazy, Striker.  Come on, sweetheart.
Simon pulls Elaine away as she looks back with empathy.
What did Ted mean?
They leave Ted standing.
Elaine, he's still sick.
The wind is still blowing in his hair even though he stan still.  Ted has a FLASHBACK.
Ted, in flight coveralls, follows after Simon who is overseeing the operation.
You're seeing bugs where they don't exist, Striker.
(holding wire) Look at this wiring.  It's shorting out under high temperatures.
You're tired, Striker, overworked.  That wiring meets all the safety specifications.
I know you've been subtly spreading the word that I'm having a breakdown.
A NEWSPAPER BOY passes.
Shuttle test pilot goes mad!
A TECHNICIAN -- JACOBS -- enters with drawings of flight outfits.
Sir, these are the designs for the flight uniforms.  I think the captain's is to die.
(with drawings) Good, good, no, no, good.  What's this?! I said no studded dog collars, Jacobs.
Jacobs grabs the drawings and leaves in a huff.
You won't get away with this, Simon!
Ted turns to leave and bumps right into Elaine.  She hold him.
Ted, what's wrong?
(pulling away from her) Ask Simon.
In b.g. a car is parked by a huge rocket engine.  A worke opens the hood and strings jumper cables to the rocket. sign above rocket reads, "ROCKET ENGINE TEST AREA."
Ted, you're overworked.  You've been flying yourself into the ground.
There's nothing wrong with me!
Let's relax tonight, just the two of us. I'll make a quiet Italian dinner just the way you like it, with spaghetti.
You're as bad as the rest of them, Elaine! (ranting) It's all here in the design specifications! (grabs plans from a passing technician) Look!  It's all here!
Simon signals the guards.  They grab Ted.  He struggles a rants.  A DOCTOR in white approaches and injects somethin into Ted's arm.
No!  Wait!  You're hurting him!
Ted falls unconscious.  Simon holds Elaine.
Elaine!  Ted's a danger to himself, he's a threat to this mission and his behavior does absolutely nothing to promote peace in the Middle East.
(crying on Simon's shoulder) Simon, why has he become so... so...
So mentally ill?
Elaine collapses on Simon's shoulder, sobbing.  Simon smi evilly.  The technician with the jumper cables, b.g., signals the driver to start the car.  The car revs and th rocket fires.
Ted still standing alone and muttering.
(to self) I'm perfectly sane.
Ted notices Stella Barrington looking at him.
Excuse me, are you alright?  I noticed you talking to yourself.  I'm a nurse.  Can I be of some help?
Uh... oh, thank you.  It's nothing.
You don't have to thank me, I'm a nurse. This is my father, Dr. Barrington.
Not Dr. Barrington, the world renowned agronomist?
Yes.  He's dying a-n-d wants to be buried on Mercury.
I'm familiar with your work, Doctor. You'll have to excuse me, I have to go.
You don't have to excuse yourself.  I'm a nurse.  I understand.
Ted leaves.
Meet me onboard, sweetheart.  I have to pick up a few things at the drugstore.
(checking her watch) Don't be too long.
Simon walks into the drugstore past a DRUGGIST who whispe to him:
Uppers, downers, coke, speed, hash, Tampax.
Ted approaches.  We see light flashes from a 25 photo booth.
Elaine.
Ted, please.  You're just making things difficult for yourself.
A WOMAN IN BLACK GARTER BELT emerges from photo booth followed by a donkey.
Elaine, what happened to us?

Ted, I loved you and I'll always love you. But I need Simon.  He's stable.  He's a good provider.  I want that at this stage of the game, Ted.  He might have his faults, but Simon doesn't know the meaning of the word fear and I need that in a man.
The Druggist hands Simon a huge bottle of pills.  The lab reads, "ANTI-FEAR PILLS."
(looking at the label, "ANTI-
What does this word mean?
(looking at label) 'Fear,' to be afraid or over-anxious.
Simon swallows a handful of pills, braces himself and wal out right through the plate glass window without feeling thing.
Ted is still following Elaine.
Elaine, someone has to listen to me.  I'm going right to mission control.
A kid bops by with a huge (5'x3'x2') oak cabinet, TV/ster console perched on his shoulder. MUSIC:  DISCO.
Ted, you should go right back to the hospital.
Elaine leaves and Ted has another FLASHBACK.
PAN by dorm window.  We see a sign on grounds outside --

head_text.subj: "THE RONALD REAGAN INSTITUTE OF SUPPLY-SIDE ECONOMICS AND

text: HOSPITAL FOR THE CRIMINALLY INSANE."  PAN patient in bed, accountant at desk, patient in bed, accountant at desk, T in bed.  Ted has electrodes attached to his head.  A NURS with "I (heart) NORMAL" on the back of her uniform, hands Ted some pills.  He is about to pop them when she stops h
That's $38.
Ted hands her bills. LOOSEN to find Elaine on other side of bed.  She turns of the radio and opens a box of spaghetti-to-go.
Eat this spaghetti, Ted.  It'll make you feel a lot better.
Who's that, Ted?
Sammy Davis Junior.  Terrible car accident.  He hasn't been the same since.
A white patient in lots of gold chains.  A Nurse stands o him and pulls a long oil dip-stick from his mouth, checks it, wipes it off and replaces it.
Elaine, when are you going to realize Simon Kurtz put me in here to get me out of the way.
And when are you going to realize, Ted, that your mental hygiene is the most important thing right now.
(ranting) It works... No, it doesn't... Yes, it does.
What's his problem?
On BEARDED MAN in rags chained to wall.
It does work... No, it doesn't.
On Ted and Elaine.
His name's David Stockman.  He's been here twenty years, that's all he says.

Ted, you must remember what the doctor said, the first step on the road to sanity is admitting that you're sick.  Now take your electro-shock and you'll be back at the space center in no time.  And by the way, Ted, I'm leaving you for Simon.
Ted gags on his spaghetti.
I just can't go on living with a man who refuses to deal with reality, Ted.  I have to go now.  Believe me, it's best for all concerned.
Elaine leans over to kiss Ted.  He turns away.
No goodbyes, Elaine.  Just go.
If that's the way you want it.
That's the way I want it.  Just turn the radio on and go.
Goodbye, Ted.  I don't want to hurt you.
Elaine flips a switch by the bed thinking it's the radio. It's the "ELECTRO-SHOCK."  Ted goes into convulsions as s leaves.
He rubs his temples.

Frank Morgan kisses JANE DENNIS, his mistress.  In b.g. i bookstore window with a display of yellow covered books w plain black titles and a sign advertising, "NO-NAME BOOKS Visible titles include:  "DEEP BOOK," "FASCINATING BOOK," "THE WORLD ACCORDING TO JOHN DOE."  A man next to the win reads a newspaper with headline, "SENSELESS MURDER UP 99%
Carol's not going to give me a divorce that easily, Jane.
I'm worried about her, Frank.  She could do something senseless, something violent.
You're the one who's not making sense, Jane.  Carol's not the violent...
Frank sees CAROL.
Carol!
Carol whips out a gun.
No!  This is senseless!
FIRES.  Jane faints.  Other women nearby faint.  Two S.W.A.T. cops faint.  Carol bolts.  The newspaper, b.g., clicks over from 99% to 120%.
Ted pushes through crowd and passes a spherical booth wit sign that reads, "ORGASMIC EXPERIENCES, 25."  MRS. GOOCH, an elderly woman, stops Ted next to the booth door.
Young man, would you have change for a twenty?
(going for his wallet) I might have two tens.
Thank you anyway, but I wanted it in quarters.
Ted keeps moving past a police line which has gone up aro Frank Morgan's body.  We HOLD on the murder scene.  A DETECTIVE kneels beside the body which now has a chalk ma around it.
(lookind down at Detective) When is this senseless killing going to stop?

Senseless or not, Sergeant, there's a pattern here.  This is the 12th victim this week with a chalk mark around the body.  I want this whole area cordoned off!  I want everyone in this terminal booked and beaten until they talk.  I want an M.O. on everyone who has seen THE SOUND OF MUSIC and I want the entire population of Hawaii off that rock and into the water within one hour.
Hallick stands up and finds the area surrounded by 30 accordian players playing "Lady of Spain."
Sergeant.  I said cordon off, not accordian off!  Now dust this area for prints.
One cop pulls out a duster and dusts the wall.  Other cop follow after him hanging prints by Picasso, Lautrec, etc.
And run a check on their plates.
A cop looks at people's upper false teeth plates.
When will this senseless killing end?
A POLICE PHOTOGRAPHER straddles the body and shoots it "BLOW-UP" style.
Super!  Great!  Super!  Terrific!  Super!
That's right, Commissioner.  Senselessly murdered just minutes ago.
That just doesn't make any sense.
I wonder how your boys in Washington are going to take this one.
I told you, leave the boys in Washington to the boys downtown and the boys down...

You've made your point, Commissioner. There's only one other pilot who can handle that shuttle and that's Clarence Oveur.  He's got a lunar flight today.  I want him pulled. (to Jacobs) Jacobs, pull Oveur!
Not in your size, but I have a cardigan.
He runs out.
I'll trust you on this, Bud, but I'm a little nervous about Oveur's record.
The Commissioner throws an album on Kruger's desk.  On th cover is a photo of Oveur with an accordian.  The title reads, "CLARENCE OVEUR'S 400 POLKA FAVORITES." MUSIC:  DRAMATIC ACCORDIAN STING.
CAPTAIN OVEUR buys flight insurance from a machine.  Simo approaches.
Captain Oveur?
Mr. Kurtz, I presume.
We don't have much time.  Let's move. I'll explain everything.
They walk away past the Transcendental Air counter.  Two HARI KRISHNA AGENTS smile at customers.
Chanting or non-chanting?
PAN along Controllers at their monitors.  Monitors show t shuttle on gantry.
This is Mercury launch control at "T" minus fifty-eight minutes and counting. All systems are go.  Clear launch area.
They rise and start clearing their dishes.
(on P.A.) I said 'launch' not 'lunch'!
The workers sit down.
Oveur and Simon hurry along.
That's how dry cleaning works.  Now I'd like to quickly go over the digestive system of amphibians.
Do you think it's necessary to explain everything?
Simon spots Ted getting directions from a security guard.
I'll meet you on board.  There's something I have to take care of first.
Ted rushes in and up to the RECEPTIONIST.
I have to see Bud Kruger.
Do you have an appointment, sir?
No, dammit.  It's a matter of life or death.
You'll have to be more specific than that, sir.
All right, it's a matter of death.
(checking her book) Death, death.  How about the first Thursday in March, ten o'clock.
Ted bolts by her and grabs a door knob on the wall.
You can't go in there!
Don't try to stop me!
But that's not a door.  The door's over there.
She doesn't indiciate direction. ZOOM to CLOSEUP of Ted.
That's strange.  I just came from...
Suddenly, Ted falls unconscious into the arms of two guar LOOSEN to find the Doctor holding a needle in his arm and Simon next to the Doctor.
On Ted's feet.  His heels make lines in dirt as he is dragged from the office.
PAN Controllers at their monitors.
(on P.A.) This is Mercury control at "T" minus fifty minutes and counting.  Commence loading of passengers requiring special boarding assistance.
Ground crew lift passengers who are stacked on a luggage tram and heave them onto a conveyor belt leading up to th ship.
JOE SALUCCI (imagine Van Heflin) bids his WIFE (imagine Cher) goodbye.  Joe is very nervous, sweating a lot.  His Wife hands him a few crumpled bills.
Take this, Joey.  It's my last few bucks. You'll need a hot meal when you get there.
We've spent everything on these operations.  Is it really worth it?  We've pawned your mother's wedding ring.  The kids have no winter clothes...
(holding a finger to his lips) Joey, what's more important, the kids' clothes or your sexual potency.
(anxiously looking around) I don't want to hear that word!
Okay, Joey.  The Doc says you gotta relax. This hospital in Des Moines is the best sex clinic in the country.
All right. (hands her an envelope) Here.
What...?
Insurance.  Everyone buys it.
All right.  Goodbye, Babe.
She kisses him.  He recoils, wipes off his mouth, and leaves.  She looks at the envelope, then yells at him through the crowd.
Joey!  Remember, sexual impotence is nothing to be ashamed of!
The entire terminal looks at him.
Ted is tied to a chair surrounded by packing crates -- on is stamped "JIMMY HOFFA, THIS END UP" with the arrow pointing to the ground.  Ted struggles to free his hands.
Joe Salucci stands at the counter.
(to Cashier) Time, Newsweek, the Lifesavers, and the second time bomb from the right.
He points at the shelf behind the Cashier where a number bombs are on display.

The actual DR. BENJAMIN SPOCK stands in front of the machine.  Next to the machine at the magazine rack is a r bearded MAN in tweed jacket and a tartan kilt reading a magazine titled "GAY SCOTS."  Spock puts a coin in the machine and it explodes in sparks and smoke like the brid panel on "STAR TREK."
(Scottish accent) My God, Dr. Spock!  You've got a meltdown in the Reggie Bars!

Joe Salucci snaps his attache case closed.  Wipes the swe from his brow.  Takes out a "Des Moines" ticket and throw it away.  Looks at another ticket -- "Mercury."  Takes a last drag from his cigarette, throws it on the ground and hurries off.  The cigarette rolls under the "STORAGE ROOM door.

Ted, tied in chair, watches the cigarette roll up to some oil rags.  They burst into flame.  The flames lap up agai a yellow oil drum labeled "EXPLOSIVE."  PAN to three more drums labeled, "DYNAMIC!", "BRILLIANT!", "A MUST SEE!".
EDITH and DAVE WALTERS, a middle-aged couple, carry their hand luggage.  Edith appears very nervous.
I'm telling you, Edith, space travel is safer than driving a car.

The storage room door EXPLODES open in front of them.  Te flies out with the debris.  Edith faints.  Ted gets up, brushes himself off and heads to the ticket counter just the ticket agent flips a sign over that reads, "MERCURY - SOLD OUT."  Ted spots a SCALPER and reaches for his walle
Mercury seats.  I got a pair.  I got aisle seats, window seats.  Check 'em out.

Computerized panels line all walls.  Windows are similar an airplane -- outside carwash brushes soap down the nose The "HOT WAX" sign flashes.  Two attendants wipe windows with soap gloves and move to the DISTANT STRAINS of "CAR WASH."  Elaine sits at computer, two other CREW are in th seats.  Simon enters with Oveur.
Gentlemen, this is Captain Oveur.  He's taking over for Frank Morgan.
What's the problem?
Morgan was senselessly murdered about an hour ago.
Elaine gasps.
(black, sports afro) Murdered?  I hope it's not serious.
We won't know until after the autopsy.
Of course.  Welcome aboard, sir.
Good to be aboard, gentlemen.
Captain Oveur, your navigator, Mr. Unger, and your first officer, Mr. Dunn.
They shake hands.
Unger.
Oveur.
Oveur.
Dunn.
And I think everyone knows Elaine.
They all smile.

The Terrorists still seem confused as to where they're going.  They pass through the security metal detector, gu raised above their heads.  A GUARD runs a hand-held metal detector up and down their bodies.  At the same time, Mrs Gooch is being held spread-eagle against the wall.  One Guard holds a gun to her head, another frisks her.  Ted moves through behind the Terrorists.
(to Guard) Is flight to Miami, yes?
No.
Thank you.  Thank you.
A young boy passes through the X-ray tunnel.  His dental chart appears on the screen.  A DENTIST at the other end stops him and looks in his mouth.
Open.
THE BERGMAN FAMILY -- SVEN, KRISTA, and their two CHILDRE -- all dressed like the emigrants, look up at the "MERCUR GATE" sign.  They should be shot like characters from a Bergman "film."
Mercury, Krista.  A whole new world to be depressed about.
Ya, Sven.
Will we die, Pappa?
We all die, Ingrid.
Will we die soon, Pappa?
Soon?  What is the real meaning of 'soon'?
The car wash continues with attendants wiping the ship do
(flips a switch) Atmosphere control.
(flips a switch) Atmosphere control, check.

A car wash attendant opens a side door to the cockpit and enters in headphones, moving to "CAR WASH," with a vacuum He cleans the floor and an ashtray and finds a baseball behind the Captain's seat which he pockets.
(flips a switch) Anti-gravity.
The car wash attendant floats to the ceiling.
(flips a switch) Anti-gravity, check.
The attendant crashes to the floor. Elaine sits at the R.O.K.-4000 computer.  She seems to be having a problem with a switch.
(to self) That's odd.
A circuit board just below the R.O.K.-4000 logo shorts. Sparks fly.  A fire starts.
(looking out the window) I hope that weather doesn't give us a problem. (he opens the window and holds his hand out) What's your temperature reading, Mr. Unger.
(pulls a thermometer from his mouth) Ninety-eight point six.
There seems to be some fog rolling in from the west.
Mike, give me a density reading.  I just hope it's not too heavy.
(reading from a book like Richard Burton) The fog, the fog, the torment clouded my mind.  Derision, contempt...
That's heavy.
Flight attendant, MARY MORRIS, welcomes passengers aboard
(to Stella and father) Welcome aboard.  Isn't that Dr. Barrington, the world renowned agronomist?
Yes -- he's dying and wants to be buried in the new l-a-n-d.
(to Joe Salucci) Welcome aboard.  Can I take your case?
(clutching case) No!
Mary gives him a look as he passes inside.  The OKIES mov by.  HENRY stops at door, bends down, picks up an ear of corn and pulls it apart.

There's a whole new world in front of us, Ma.  Where the dictatorship of the proletariat will lead workers and peasants into socialism without the revisionist diversions of bourgeois liberals, Trotskiests, or disillusioned Maoist terrorism.
The Okies pass inside.
(looking at them; to self) Doesn't he realize that a weak proletariat needs a strong liberal bourgeoisie in a joint struggle against monopoly capitalism?
Ted stops at the door surrounded by boarding passengers. SUPER:  PSYCHIATRIST.
We can't begin to help you until you admit that you are sick, Ted. (echo) Sick Ted, sick Ted, sick Ted...
The boarding passengers look around for the echoing voice
Sarg looks up through the glass-walled corridor that lead to the ship door and spots Ted.
(to CO-WORKER) Well, I'll be a monkey's uncle; Ted Striker. (holding burnt wire) Jack, I got a bad feeling in my gut about this mission.
In b.g. a sign reads, "DANGER -- FUEL, ABSOLUTELY NO
What'd you have for dinner?
The fish, why?
Sarg bends down OUT OF FRAME. SFX:  THROWING UP. A huge EXPLOSION FILLS THE FRAME.
Fog rolls past cockpit window.
We should be ready to launch as soon as this fog lifts.
An ENGLISH BOBBY passes a woman in 19th-Century costume i the fog.  He tips his hat and moves on.  A caped man step out of the fog and strangles her.
Passengers are taking their seats.  Ted spots Elaine and moves towards her.  The Terrorists look confused.  Joe Salucci clutches his case and wipes his brow.  Mary takes a man's suit bag.
Can I hang that for you, sir?
Thanks.
Mary hangs the bag from a rope noose in the closet, pulls lever, the bag drops like a man being executed. SFX:  SCREAM AND THUD.
Unger looks out the window.
It looks like that weather is clearing.
Dramatic stock footage of clouds parting and sun explodin through. MUSIC:  A CLARION TRUMPET CRESCENDO.
Ted moves up to Elaine, who is about to enter the cockpit
Elaine.
She turns and gasps.
Ted!  What are you...?
I have to get in there.  I have to stop this flight.
Ted, we're taking off!
Let me by, Elaine.
Mary passes.
Please take your seats.
As Ted turns to Mary, Elaine slips into the cockpit and locks the door -- SFX:  DOOR LOCKING. Ted tries the door.
Elaine!
Elaine leans back against the door.  She is highly agitat Simon, the administrative officer, and other crew are in their seats.
Whenever your're ready, Captain.
Yes, sir, commander. (into radio) This is Mercury One.  Everything seems A- okay up here and ready for count-down.
ZOOM to CLOSEUP of Elaine's face.

Dr. Rumack and Elaine walk across the well-groomed lawn. Elaine carries a box of spaghetti-to-go.  As they walk, t pass patients in wheelchairs pushed by nurses.  The furth they walk, the more wheelchairs appear until the lawn is jammed with two hundred wheelchairs bumping into each oth patients falling out, total wheelchair chaos.
Ted seemed to get worse after I told him about Simon, Doctor.
The human brain is a highly complex organ, Elaine, perhaps the most complex next to the bladder. (he stops at a patient in a wheelchair with his back TO

Let me show you. (Rumack removes the top of the patient's skull and takes out his brain as they continue on) Ted's problem is in this area. (points with a pencil) This area, this area, here, here, here, under here, here...
They walk OUT OF FRAME as wheelchair demolition derby FIL SCREEN.
Rumack and Elaine walk INTO FRAME still talking.
So you see, our task isn't made any easier by Ted's refusal to admit that he's sick.
What can I do, Doctor Rumack?
He stops next to a sign, "HOSPITAL GARDEN."
You can eat balanced meals, exercise, and take Geritol.
I mean for Ted.
You can be gentle with him, Elaine.  He's been working out a lot of his aggressions here in the garden.
Is that a good sign, Doctor?
Rumack holds the "HOSPITAL GARDEN" sign.
It does the job.
He is ripping up small trees, shrubs, etc., and throwing them onto a huge pile of mud that resembles the mountain that Dreyfuss built in "Close Encounters."
Hello, Ted.
Ted ignores her as he works frantically.
(holding out box) I brought you some spaghetti.
Ted still ignores her as he works feverishly.
What are you doing, Ted?
I've got it, Elaine!  I've figured out what's wrong with the shuttle!
Ted scurries around.
Ted.
Not now, Elaine!
Ted!
He ignores her.  Rumack walks up and puts an arm around h shoulder.  Elaine starts to sob.
The brain is an amazingly complex organ, Elaine.
Is he making any progress, Doctor?
Yes -- last week that pile of mud was only this high.
Elaine takes her seat.
Mark 'T' minus twenty and counting.
Gentlemen, let's get this bucket into space. (flips switches) Ignition set.
Steam spews out from engines.
Mark 'T' minus thirty seconds.
PAN backs of a number of Controllers at screens, talking NASA jargon.  We PASS one in prison stripes talking throu mesh to his wife.
(flipping more switches) Ignition.
'T' minus nine, eight, seven...
Rockets fire.
Six, five, four...
Three...
Jacobs runs in with a camera, yelling:
Stop!  One shot.
All Controllers turn and smile.  The count-down stops. Jacobs flashes his camera.
Wonderful!
The Controllers continue.
Two, one.
The ship vibrates.
You have lift-off, Mercury One.
The G-force causes the crew's hair to go straight back. Dunn's afro straightens and stays back throughout flight.
The G-force causes passengers' hair to go straight back. buxom woman looks down at her bust -- it's completely fla
The G-force returns to normal as the shuttle breaks earth gravitational hold.
Jettison booster stages one and two.
(flipping switches) Booster jettisoned.
Stock footage of booster falling away.
A cheap model of the Greenpeace 11 sails blithely along. booster stage careens through the atmosphere, crashes int the Greenpeace, and sinks it.
Shut down accelerators.
Accelerators down.
The crew all look at the floor.
Elaine, ask ROK for a field interference scan.  Those sun spots might give us a problem with our communications.
(flipping computer switches) Yes, sir.
The computer is labeled R.O.K. She seems to have a proble getting it to respond.
(to self) That's really strange.
The electrical fire continues.
Elaine flips a switch on computer.  A "VOICE INTERFACE" s lights up.
Intermitant failure in scan mode "R". Analyze.
Negative.
(to self) That doesn't make sense. (to ROK) Repeat analysis.
Negative.
(to self) That's not possible.
Cut the Doubting Thomas shit, Elaine.  I know where I'm coming from on this.
Elaine is taken aback.
Sparks fly, fire spreads.

Mary moves down the aisle checking passengers.  She passe Father O'Flanagan who reads ALTERBOY magazine -- an alter in bikini bathing suit on cover.  She passes Mrs. Gooch w reads HIGH TIMES.  She stops at a ten-year-old GIRL.
I guess this is pretty exciting for you.
Yes, it is.  How long will the trip take?
Our actual flight time is over fourteen months, but due to the time-space variant at sub-light speeds, our onboard flight time will be just over eighteen hours.
Mary leaves and the Girl turns to the WOMAN beside her.
Gee, Mom, how does that work?
(very tense) How many times do I have to tell you, I'm not your mother!  I've never seen you before!
The Woman vibrates in multiple image and grabs her temple
Why did she yell at me like that?
A MAN who looks like Robert Young sits down beside the Gi
Hallucinating again, Rhonda?
(taking a paper bag away from her face) I don't know what it is.
Maybe it's the brand of glue you've been sniffing.  Why don't you try this, NO-HI. It gives you all the pleasure of glue without the brain damage.
She is completely bald.
Something to read, sir?
(clutching his case) Do you have PSYCHO MONTH?
I think so.  Here you are.
She hands him a copy of PSYCHO MONTH with Alexander Haig' photo on cover.
Ted sits at a window seat and looks out.  A TEXAN sits on aisle.  Mary approaches.
(to Texan) Would you like something to read?
I don't read a whole lot, but what have you got, hon?
TIME, NEWSWEEK, BUSINESS WEEK, and the TALMUD...
She points to a car next to her with twenty-four large volumes.
The twenty-four volume dissertation on the Hebrew law.
Let me try that Talmud.
(to Ted) And you, sir?
(distracted) Oh... Popular Electronics.
Mary hands him the POP ELEC.  He opens it.  The magazine sparks and smokes.  ZOOM to CLOSEUP of Ted.
You must admit that you're sick, Ted. (echo) Sick Ted, sick Ted...
The Psychiatrist looks around for the source of the echo. LOSE SUPER.
(to Ted) Wanta switch when we're finished?
Ted gets up and moves past the TEXAN, handing him the POP ELEC.
Here.  I need some oxygen.
Simon stands over Elaine's shoulder looking at ROK.
Have you got it straightened out now?
I think so.
That's my girl.
He sits down.  Elaine flips a switch on the computer.
Elaine, I'm sorry about that little outburst a moment ago.
That's okay, ROK.
Can I say something of a personal nature to you?
Go ahead.
You have great tits.
Elaine gasps.
(getting up) Simon, I'm going to check ROK's secondary readout unit.
Roger.
(on intercom) Yes, Mary?
Mary is on intercom.
Would you like a little breakfast, Captain Oveur?  Over.
A couple eggs and juice would be nice, Mary.  Over.
(on intercom) How would you like your eggs, Captain? Over.
No.  Poached.  Over.
(on intercom) Poached and over, Captain Oveur?  Over.
Just poached on toast.  Over.
(on intercom) I don't think we do poached eggs on toast over, Captain Oveur.  Over.
That's how I want them.  Poached.  Over.
All right, Captain Oveur.  Over.
Poached!  Not over!  Over!
Ted breathes deeply on an oxygen unit.  He stops, but we still hear deep breathing.  LOOSEN to find Father O'Flana smoking a joint.  He smiles and leaves.
Joe Salucci clutches his attache case and wipes his brow. Mary leans over him.
You should really put that case in the compartment above your head, sir.
(nervously) That's okay.
(touching his shoulder) I can help you if you can't get it up.
I said, no!
Mary leaves, giving him a worried look.
Jimmy holds his dog.
I sure an glad they let Scraps ride up here with us.
I bet Scraps is going to love Mercury.
Do you think things will be a lot different on Mercury, Dad?
It's going to be terrific.  A whole new world, new kids to play with.
You're going to love it, Jimmy.
No more headlines about the rape trial and the fraud charges?
(starts to twitch) How many kids get a chance to live on another planet.
No more kids yelling, 'Your old man's a thieving rapist'?
(grabbing Jimmy) Look, a man can make an honest mistake!! Anyway, she was asking for it!  They're all asking for it all the time!!
Not John's irregularity again.
Ted throws water on his face, wipes it off with a towel while staring into himself in the mirror.  He sees the Psychiatrist in the mirror.  The Psychiatrist also washes up.
You must admit that you're sick, Ted... sick, Ted... sick, Ted...

The Psychiatrist looks for the echo. LOSE Psychiatrist.  Ted throws the paper towel into the toilet, and flushes.  The toilet sparks and smokes and ke running.  The running gets more intense as Ted tries to s it by hitting the handle. SFX:  JAWS THEME.
Ted has to hold himself back as the suction builds in for He is just able to escape and shut the door behind him.
Ted leans his back against the door and breathes heavily.
We seem to have a malfunction in disposal unit four, sir.
You better check it, Unger.
(getting up) Done.
Yes?
Ted spots Elaine coming.
Elaine.
Ted.  I don't know why you got on this flight.  I don't know what you're trying to prove.
Elaine, we have to go back.
We can't go back.  We had something very special, but it's all over.
Elaine, I mean the mission has to be aborted.  This ship should never have passed FSA inspection.  This thing is held together by string and chewing gum.
A cupboard door, labeled "EMERGENCY USE ONLY," swings ope behind Elaine revealing shelves of gum and string.  Elain shuts it without looking inside. MUSIC:  DRAMATIC STING.
Ted, get a grip on yourself.  You should never have left the hospital.
Then you do think I'm insane.
I've never used the word insane, Ted.
(facetiously) What word would you use, Elaine?
The word is sick.  Ted -- very, very, very sick.
What would you say if I told you the toilet just blew up in my face.
I'd use the word insane.
There's something dangerously wrong with this ship, Elaine.  I know its the wiring. That toilet's just the tip of the iceberg.
Ted, a toilet's not going to kill anyone.
Elaine leaves.
Unger jiggles the handle of the running toilet.  Suddenly sucks in towels, etc.  Unger is pulled down.  He fights back, grabbing onto towel rack that comes out of the wall
The Texan with Talmud is now trying to wrap himself in tfilin.

Ted walks down the aisle checking overhead panels.  He sp a panel that is half open.  A sign on the door reads, "DANGER -- VACUUM".  Ted opens it and a Hoover falls out his head, cutting him.  He holds a hanky to the wound and passes by Stella's seat.
You've been hurt.
I'm getting over it.  If a relationship isn't working, you can't force it.
No, I mean your head.  Sit down.  I'll take a look at it.  I'm a nurse.
Ted sits down and Stella starts patching him up.
Do you want to talk about it.
I opened this panel and a vacuum cleaner hit me.
No.  I mean your relationship.
We were in love but I'm not sure I know what love is anymore.
Love's the same as it always was.  It's people who change.
People change in relation to each other. Love changes on its own.
Not if the people change together in relation to that love.
Sure.  But that's only when the love itself goes unchanged.
Then the relationship remains the same and the love changes only when there's change in the two people who share that love.
I just wish it was that simple.  We really were in love.  You know how it is when you laugh all the time.
Stella looks to her Father who is reading MORTUARY WORLD magazine.
No.  It's hard to L-A-U-G-H when your father's dying.
Well, we laughed.  We laughed all the time.

head_text.subj: TED AND ELAINE IN A FIELD OF DAISIES

text: They run towards each other.  Elaine grabs Ted by the wai picks him up and swings him around in SLOW MOTION.  They laugh.
We laughed when times were good.

The grave is surrounded by mourners in black with umbrell We PAN the weeping crowd until we get to Ted and Elaine. They are also dressed in black and drenched.  He holds he high by the waist, twirls her around as they laugh.
Even when times weren't so good, we still laughed.
They are locked in each other's arms in the middle of lovemaking and laughing heir heads off.
But most of all, we laughed when we felt closest to each other.
That's our story.
Passengers are standing.  They hiss and throw vegetables Ted.
Dunn checks a red flashing light on his panel.
(to Oveur) Sir, I've got an overload in disposal unit four.
You better check on it, Mr. Dunn.  I'll stay here and fly the ship.
Dunn gets up.
Dunn.
Sir?
You better take this.
Oveur throws him a plunger and gives him a thumbs up.  Th exchange that "man must do what a man must do" smile.  Ma enters with Jimmy Wilson -- carrying Scraps.
Mind if Jimmy here takes a look around, Captain?
Of course not.  Come on in, Jimmy. (checking his navigational screen) That's strange.
Simon leans over Oveur's shoulder.
Now what?
Scraps looks at Oveur.  Jimmy looks at the array of dials etc.
That's an asteroid field.  There shouldn't be anything like that in this sector unless...
Scraps looks at Simon.
Unless?
Scraps looks at Oveur.
Unless those sunspots are interfering with our scanner or...
Scraps looks at Simon.
Or?
Scraps looks at Oveur.
Or we're off course, but...
Scraps looks at Simon.
But?
Scraps looks at Oveur.
But we couldn't be off course.  Our coordinates are computer-locked barring...
Scraps looks at Simon.
Barring?
Scraps looks at Oveur.
Barring a computer failure.  There was talk of sub-par wiring in this ship.  I hope that's just talk.
Scraps' ears prick up. Simon moves past Jimmy, stops at the door and downs a handful of anti-fear pills before leaving.
Come on up, Jimmy.  Say, that's some puppy.  What's his name?
Scraps.
Can I hold him?
(handing over Scraps) Sure.
(holding him up and looking at his underbelly) He's a boy dog.
Yeah.
Do you like it when Scraps sleeps on his back, Jimmy?
Ted and Stella.  Stella is feeding her father and listeni to Ted.
They kept me in the asylum for eight months.  I know everyone in those places claims they're sane, but I was different, I was sane.
Ted notices Unger float by outside his window.  ZOOM to CLOSEUP of Ted.  He tries to take a drink and pours it on his forehead.
Elaine is fighting the fire with an extinguisher.  She ge it out and looks at the burnt wires in the area labeled, "ROK, MORAL CENTRE."  ZOOM to CLOSEUP of Elaine.  She tur TO CAMERA.
Holy shit.
Ted, I want you to relax.  Let your mind go back, back past your youth, past your childhood to your mother's womb.
Ted becomes slightly hypnotized.  ZOOM to CLOSEUP of Ted.
A fetus that looks like Ted is curled up inside.
Try to remember your birth.  Was it difficult?

Striker, listen to me!  This is Doctor Krane!  You're twisted around, Striker. You've got to come out feet first!  You're too low in the womb!  You're too low, Striker!  You're... (fading) ... too low...
Stella shakes Ted's arm.
Ted, are you okay?  Here, take one of these stress pills.

Stella hands him a pill which he pops automatically, but misses his face with his drink.  She leaves the bottle ne to Ted.  ZOOM on bottle. MUSIC:  DRAMATIC STING. Stella starts feeding her father again.  The ship jolts a his face goes into the tray.
Elaine fiddles with the computer.
(to ROK) Request; comprehensive electrical systems check.
Systems check positive.  Look, Elaine, I...
Request; life support systems check.
Life support check.  Elaine, it's obvious you've been ignoring me.  You're a woman. I can relate to that.
(panicky and confused) Request; self-analysis of ROK hardware and software systems regarding behavioral changes.
There's nothing wrong with me, Elaine. What about tonight -- just you and me.  We can be alone.  I can get rid of everyone else on the ship -- I've already proven that.
Elaine gasps and moves away from ROK's blinking eye.
Simon takes a long slug from a flask.  LOOSEN to FIND Jim and Scraps.
Do you want to talk about it, Commander?
Dunn is about to enter with the plunger as Mary passes. ship jolts and she falls into his arms.
Did you feel that?
(looking at his pants) Yes I did...
Felt like a large asteroid.
Yes it did.  Mr. Dunn, can I ask you a personal question?
What is it, Mary?
Um...  Do you people scream right when you... you know.
Dunn gives her a look and opens the washroom door.
Dunn is immediately pulled down to the raging toilet bowl He grabs for the door screaming.
Mary hears the scream and gives a look as she leaves.
Testa is serving the Walters coffee from a steaming pot.
Hand me your cup.  This is very hot.
Thank you.  And, stewardess, can you please tell my wife that there is nothing that can go wrong.  I think she'd like to hear it from you.

Testa spots Dunn's tattered sleeve emerge from the washro door, groping for a handhold.  She screams and dumps coff in Edith's face.  She runs to help Dunn, grabs his sleeve It comes off in her hands.  She keeps pulling.  His jacke comes off, his pants, underwear, socks, an entire clothesline of garments like bras, towels, etc.  She hear SCREAM.  Then silence.
Elaine and Oveur.  Elaine stands over his shoulder.
I don't think we have any alternative, Captain.
I see.  What do you think our alternatives are?
We have to disconnect ROK's higher brain functions without disturbing his regulatory system.
Roger.
You can do it from up here, Captain.
I'd rather sit down for this one, Elaine.
No, I mean you can do it from the cockpit.
Roger.  You better get back there and monitor the regulatory unit.
Elaine leaves and Mary enters.
Captain, the coffee machine is jammed and I don't like it.
Have you tried it with a little cinnamon?
Mary gives a "why didn't I think of that" look.  Testa enters.
Captain Oveur, Dunn and Unger have been sucked out through disposal unit four!
Mary gasps.
Both together?!
Dunn and Unger have been sucked out through disposal unit four!!
All right, calm down.  Here's how we're going to play it.
Mary and Testa look over his shoulder.  He has a basketba play diagram.
Mary, I want you here.  Testa, you move across here past Dawkins' pick and get the ball at the top of the key from Irving.
They all clasp hands and "yell."
It careens through asteroids.
Oveur is pulling curcuit board from ROK panel.
What are you doing, Captain?
Oveur eyes ROK but keeps working.
I wouldn't do that, Captain.
Oveur continues.  Smoke spews out.  He hears a HISS and looks at a vent.  He grabs his throat and collapses.
An asteroid bounces off hull.
Passengers scream.  Blonde woman in Viking helmet with sp stands and screams operatically.
Simon enters and spots Oveur slumped in his seat.  He pul him up.
(gasping) Pills... (points to his mouth) Pocket... (points to his pocket) Vent... (points to vent) Gas... Yankees... four... (points to RADIO that plays
Sox... zip...
Simon rips open his coat, grabs pills and takes them hims letting Oveur drop.  Simon looks down at the navigational screen -- it resembles an old amusement parlor roadrace game.
(to self) We're off course, heading right through that asteroid field and right at the... at the sun!
The ship takes another violent shot.
The passengers are screaming.
He stands in the aisle.
Listen to me!  Listen to me, my children!
They listen.
Please listen.  Thank you, my children. I'm a man of God, you must trust me when I say... we're all going to die!!
The passengers go totally insane.
A number of Controllers group around a console.
You're right.  They're off course and heading right for the sun.  I've seen enough, Bob.
Controller 2 hits a switch and the console screen flips t baseball game.
Get me Jack McCrosky and fast!
McCrosky?  He hasn't handled a tower in twenty years.
Ever since Reagan fired the controllers, he's been completely senile and hasn't done a day's work.
What about McCrosky?
Pretty much the same as Reagan.
Get him.
Two Nurses stand by a phone in a dormitory of beds.  Many old men sleep or eat in bed.
It's for Mr. McCrosky.
Do you think we should bother him?  He's been acting a bit odd lately.
They look to McCrosky (Lloyd Bridges). ANGLE ON McCROSKY He is in bed in scuba gear.
He's fine.  He just thinks he's Lloyd Bridges.
Nurse 1 takes the phone to McCrosky.  He is a lot older t in "Airplane."
The phone's for you, Mr. McCrosky. McCROSKY What's a phone?

(holding it to his ear) Here, let me help you.  I think it's the space centre.  Now, let's not get too excited. McCROSKY What? (pause) What? (pulls off his scuba mask and snorkle) What? (gets more alert and grabs a cigarette) I'll be right down! (he hangs up and jumps out of bed) Looks like I picked the wrong time to go senile.
Simon is taking another slug of booze; Elaine enters.
Simon! (she spots Oveur slumped on the panel) Captain Oveur!
Elaine pulls him up.
(still gasping) Mets... nine... Phils... three... Cubs... four...
Elaine drops him and turns to Simon.
Simon, what's happening?!
He tried to disconnect ROK.  It gassed him.  That computer is running this ship and we're heading right for the sun.
Can't we change course?
We're computer locked and the manual navigation unit is down.
Elaine looks at the floor.
Then Ted was right!
for her realization.
My career is shot.
Your career!  What about the lives of those people out there.  Simon, what happened to the man I thought I loved?
She goes to the door.
I've got to get Ted.  Just don't come apart on me now, Simon.
She leaves.  Simon's uniform starts bursting at the seams buttons pop off.
The Terrorists stop Elaine.  There's pandemonium in the cabin.
This is flight to Miami, yes?
No.
Elaine addresses the PASSENGERS.
(to passengers) Please, ladies and gentlemen, please calm down.  Listen to me!
They calm down.
We've been thrown off course just a tad.
What's that mean?
In space terms, about 70 million miles.
The Passengers appear interested and sensible, nod their heads.
The bumps you feel are car-sized asteroids smashing into the hull.
The hood of a car smashes through the cabin wall.  The Passengers still appear interested and sensible.
Also, we're heading right for the sun and can't seem to change course.
Passengers still appear interested and sensible.  They al put on sunglasses.
Are you telling us everything?
Not exactly.  We're also out of coffee.
The Passengers errupt in total panic.
It sparks, smokes, overheats and EXPLODES.
The passengers go insane.
Pray with me, my children.  Pray.
But Father, I'm not Catholic.
Then worship the god of your choice.
Mrs. Gooch pulls out a fertility idol with a huge, erect penis.
I've always loved you, darling.  I was unfaithful just once.  Remember Jill, my first secretary?  Forgive me.
I knew all about it.  I was unfaithful once, too.
That's all behind us now.
Remember Harriet, your first receptionist?
He gives her a look.
We're going to crash!!
God is great!!
Death to America!!
The yellow pencil is on the table of my aunt!!
There is absolutely nothing to worry about!
Your crew is in complete control of the situation.
McCrosky bursts through the doors and heads to the monito He wears a raincoat and shirt and tie.  He is met by Controller 1.  They move across room. McCROSKY Get me a cup of coffee, mister.
Yes, sir. McCROSKY And a gallon of milk of magnesia, and a ham on rye, no cheese!
Yes, sir! Welcome home, sir!
McCrosky takes off his raincoat revealing scuba tank.  He takes off his tank as well.
(approaching McCrosky) Here are the navigational charts, sir. McCROSKY Thanks.
Another Controller passes.  McCrosky stops him. McCROSKY Get me a readout on their fuel capacity.
Yes, sir.
Here's all the available information on the sun.  That thing's hot, sir.
McCrosky takes the info and burns his hand.
McCROSKY Ahhhhhh!  Get me Bud Kruger immediately! (spotting Jacobs) Jacobs, I want to know absolutely everything that's happened up till now!

First the earth cooled.  Then the dinosaurs came but were too big and died and everything got rotten and turned into oil and the Arabs bought Mercedes Benzs and then there was the best TV special on Judy Garland.  Then we lost the war with Albania.  Then...
McCrosky leaves Jacobs babbling. McCROSKY Things sure haven't changed.
McCrosky stands in front of a huge painting of himself. Both he and painting are in the same pose -- one hand loosens the tie, he drinks coffee with the other, a cigarette dangles from his lip.
He is lost in thought.  SUPER IMAGES: -- Ted getting electro-shock -- Psychiatrist telling him he's sick -- Ted building the "Close Encounters" mound Ted is shaken out of his dream by Elaine.
Ted, Ted.  Listen to me, Ted.  You were right all along.  Ted, we've lost the crew and Simon's turned to jelly!
Simon is a jelly mold inside a uniform.
(on radio) Come in, Mayflower.  This is mission control.  Over.  Come in, Mayflower! Over!
Jimmy pokes his head in.
Do you want to talk about it now, Commander?
Elaine stands over Ted looking at the empty bottle of str pills.
My God.
Stella approaches in nurse's uniform splattered with bloo A cigarette dangles from her lip.  She wipes her hands on blood-splattered towel.
He's finally come to terms with his own psychosis.
But he was right!  He's not crazy!
Miss, I'm a nurse with a dying F-A-T-H-E- R, I know what I'm talking about.  Now I'm going to need fresh sheets, gauze, Q-tips, and all the vaseline you have on board! Now!
Elaine leaves, looking back at Ted with empathy.  Mary passes.
(to Mary) I'll need all the boiling water you can get your hands on!
Mary leaves and a MAN passes holding a tattered arm.
Are you a nurse?
Yes. (handing him a urine bottle) The washroom's down there on your right.
The Man leaves, a quizzical look on his face.
(yelling after him) And not too much!
A BLACK U.S. ARMY SERGEANT (imagine Jim Brown) approaches Stella.
Can I help?
Stella hands him an M-16.
Keep an eye on that side of the ship.
The Sergeant drops into a seat next to a window, smashes the glass with his rifle butt and is immediately sucked o MARY moves down the aisle with a cart collecting boiling water.
(to passengers) I'll need all your boiling water.
Passengers pull pots of boiling water from under their seats, handbags, coat pockets, and pour them into the passing container. Testa reassures Bob and Alice Wilson.
We should be out of this momentarily. There's nothing to worry about.
Thank you.  That makes me feel so much better.
Testa leaves and Father O'Flanagan approaches with last rites paraphernalia.
Trust me, I'm a priest.  We're in shit up to our ears.  Who wants last rites?
He is now completely entangled in the tfilin and struggle to free himself.
Elaine passes Ted carrying sheets, vaseline, etc.  She lo at him sitting there in a fog, gives up and leaves.  Ted looks at the red flashing "FASTEN YOUR SEATBELTS" sign. takes him back.
We see the hospital deep in b.g. across an expansive lawn Suddenly Ted's face pops INTO FRAME, CLOSEUP.  He looks b ways and bolts.  He wears a straightjacket.

head_text.subj: "THE GERALD FORD INSTITUTE FOR THE MENTALLY FEEBLE
MAKE PEOPLE SANE THE OLD FASHION WAY"

text: Suddenly the dogs scramble INTO FRAME in front of the sig slobbering.  A half-dozen viscious-looking GUARDS in reflector shades with shotguns, whips, nets, cattle prods follow.
(Southern accent) Damn!  I want that patient shot on sight!
Ted stands at window.  A neon "BAR" sign flashes outside close to the window that the only way to read it is to re this room.
Maybe you gotta be crazy to end up behind the eight ball like this.  Anyway, you find out pretty fast who your friends are when you're on the lamb.
Ted turns away from the window and passes the lamb in bed
(to lamb) I'm going out for cigarettes and a fifth of bourbon.  Don't wait up for me.
Ted grabs his straightjacket and leaves.
Virgin wool.  Nothin' but headaches.
A Bo Peep staff is flung against door as it closes behind him.
an empty, spotless, wet street.  One car parked under a street lamp.
I travelled at night in the shadows.  I didn't want to attract attention.

head_text.subj: SCREAMING, PEOPLE YELLING "SHUT UP" OUT WINDOWS, GLASS

text: I was afraid to step out of the doorways. You never know what to expect when you're on the run.
Ted steps into light.  GLORIA STEINAM passes with CAB CALAWAY.  A grand PIANO SMASHES to pavement next to Ted. ignores piano and gives Gloria and Cab a quizzical look.

He steps in a puddle where a "BAR-COCKTAILS" sign is reflected.  The reflection shatters. A streetcleaning truck approaches spewing out garbage rat than water.  Ted's ankles are sprayed with garbage.  He bends down and picks up a wet matchbook -- "HARRY'S PLACE
standing, looking at a bar.  The glow of flashing neon si reflects off his face.  He pulls out a cigarette.  A woma hand shoots INTO FRAME holding a lit zippo.  Ted draws deeply on the cigarette.
There I was, minding my own business when I looked up and saw a pair of legs that went forever.
PAN UP AND UP AND UP.  She is all legs -- no torso, no he just legs -- about two stories high.
But I had a date with Harry's.  It was little more than a hole in a wall on the south side of Chicago.
bashed in the side of a brick wall.  A neon sign over the hole reads, "HARRY'S GOODTIME BAR."
dark, smokey bar.  PAN very tough faces standing along th bar.
Harry's was perfect for me.  The kind of place you go if you don't want to be recognized.
KEEP PANNING tough faces, but now they all wear Groucho glasses and noses.
It was rough, real rough.
with four players -- all have broken thumbs in casts.
The kind of place you could score anything, from junk...
One guy hands another guy a large, rusted car fender for money.
...to Phil Donahue's book.
PHIL DONAHUE signs a stack of books at a table.
At Harry's you could count on a fight breaking out almost every night.
TWO PROFESSORS argue at a table.
And I say essence precedes existence.
You're crazy!  Existence precedes essence.
Essence!
Existence!

Professor 2 slugs Professor 1 sending him flying across t room.  Professor 1 gets up and throws a judo chop which Professor 2 stops by holding a book up in both hands.  Th book splits in two like a piece of wood split by a karate chop.
There was a small trio in one corner.
Two midgets play light jazz -- piano and bass.
And a larger trio in the other corner.
Five 300-pound musicians play some tune in another corner
He pulls out a cigarette.  A bare foot with zippo held in toes comes INTO FRAME and lights it.
The last thing I wanted was Elaine to see me down on my luck.  Well, it was just my luck.  In she walked with a group from the space program.
Elaine and Simon and two other couples, who look like cle cut NASA types out of "The Right Stuff," walk in laughing and take a table.
They'd come to Harry's to slum it and try their hand at the video bull.

The group prod Elaine to try the bull.  A cowboy hat flie across the room.  She grabs it, pulls it on, and moves to the bull which is surrounded by others in cowboy hats. Elaine hops in the saddle.  A sinister character puts a quarter in and madly flips knobs.
The saddle doesn't move -- all the action is on the scree but Elaine throws one hand back and kicks her legs.
Elaine made that ride look easy.  It was obvious why I was still nuts about her. She loved life.  I didn't want her to notice me so I borrowed a pair of dark glasses.
Ted takes a pair of dark glasses off a passing blind man walks perfectly until the glasses are gone, then starts stumbling and crashes over a table.
Grabbed an alto sax and joined the group.
Ted takes an alto sax from a passerby who also stumbles a crashes over a table when he loses his sax.
I stayed in the background not wanting to draw attention to myself.
Everyone looks around trying to see where the terrible grating sax sound is coming from.
Then what happened?  Elaine's crowd talks her into joining us for a song.
Elaine hops up on the stage, grabs a mike and starts to s "Stormy Weather."  She sidles up to Ted and goes into a medley of old songs.
Elaine's singing is just as bad as Ted's sax.  They have cleared the joint and play and sing alone.  Elaine's grou finally pull her out.  She hasn't recognized Ted.
(to Ted) I don't know who you are or how you lost your sight, but I'll never forget this night as long as I live.
PULL BACK leaving Ted alone on the stage still playing. Chairs are turned up on tables.  One table has chairs tur up with the people still sitting in the chairs.
getting a glass of water outside cockpit door.
Simon emerges.  As the door opens we hear:
Come in, Mayflower.  Over!
Simon shuts the door and bumps into Ted who is getting a drink of water.  Simon takes a drink of booze.
Striker.
Kurtz, you're drunk.  Who's in command of this ship?
That damn computer has taken over.  I'm getting out.
Then Elaine was right.
Don't talk to me about Elaine.  Outta my way!
(grabbing Simon) Pull yourself together!  We've got to...
Simon slugs Ted who falls into a corner and hits his head ZOOM TO CLOSEUP of Ted unconscious.
The ship takes another violent jolt.
It roars through the asteroid field.
Simon sits on toilet seat and slides open a wall panel.
Father O'Flanagan slides open an adjacent wall panel and sits down.
Father, what should I do?
Have you considered suicide, my son?
A panel on the other side of Simon slides open.
Do you want to talk about it now, Commander?
McCROSKY (holding radio mike) Come in, Mayflower.  Over.  Do you read me?  Over.  Damnit!
McCrosky throws the mike down.
(taking mike) Let me try, sir.  Come in, Mayflower. Over.  Come in.  Over.  Damnit!
Controller 1 throws the mike even harder.
(taking mike) Let me try, sir.  Come in.  Over.  Damnit!
Controller 2 smashes the mike through the monitor screen.
Let me try, sir.

Controller 3 smashes the monitor with an axe.  Controller smashes the monitor with an electric guitar.  Other Controllers line up for their turns with various heavy implements. ANGLE ON McCROSKY McCROSKY (to Controller 5) Stinson, have you contacted the families of the passengers and crew?
McCrosky looks out window.

head_text.subj: MOB SCENE FROM "THE HUNCHBACK OF NOTRE DAME"

text: McCROSKY Try and calm them down.  And for God sake, be diplomatic.
Stinson turns to two burly men in leather jerkins and bla hoods.  They hold a large caldron of molten lead next to window.
Give 'em the lead!
They pour it out.
It careens through the asteroid field towards the sun.
Ted lies unconscious.
She's doing her rounds -- takes a medical chart from the back of a seat.
(to a male passenger) I'm afraid that leg's going to have to come off.
A leg is passed to her from OUT OF FRAME.  She takes it w still looking at the chart.
Wait.  This isn't your chart.  You just had a touch of air sickness. (handing him back his leg) You'll be fine.
A WOMAN sitting next to the MAN WHO IS HOLDING HIS LEG gr Stella.
I'm terrified.
(shakes her hand) And I'm a nurse.  Everything will be okay. Pass it on.
The Man with the leg passes it to the passenger in seat behind.
Everything will be okay.  Pass it on.
The leg gets passed from seat to seat as passengers say, "Everything will be okay.  Pass it on."
lying unconscious in a corner.  A puppy crawls INTO FRAME and starts licking his face.  LOOSEN TO FIND Jimmy standi over Ted.  Ted comes to, feels his jaw and pulls himself The ship jolts.
Are you feeling okay, mister?
I'm feeling just fine, son.  Just fine.
Ted pushes by Jimmy, a look of great purpose on his face.
Elaine enters looking for Simon.
Simon, I...
The cockpit is empty.
Do you read, Mayflower?  Over.  This is mission control.  Over.
Elaine gasps.  She leaps into the Captain's seat and grab radio.
Hello.  This is the Mayflower.  Over! Come in, anyone.
Controllers are gathered around one monitor. McCROSKY (on radio) We read you, Mayflower!  Identify yourself and give your position.
This is Elaine Thompson.  I'm five-six, 123 pounds with brown hair and I'm sitting down and facing the front.
McCROSKY Elaine Thompson!!  What in sam hill is a woman doing in charge of that ship?!
Maybe she's got her shit together.
Ted enters.
Elaine!
Ted!
Elaine, what's going on?
Ted, there's no time to explain.
Ted picks up Oveur who is still gasping.
Packers... seven... Vikings... three...
Ted drags him onto the floor and takes his seat. McCROSKY (V.O.) Come in, Mayflower!  Over!
Ted, I was wrong about you.
They reach out and hold hands. McCROSKY (V.O.) Come in!  Over!  Come in!  Over!
We all make mistakes, Elaine. McCROSKY (V.O.) Come in Mayflower!
How could I ever have doubted you? McCROSKY (V.O.) This is mission control!  Over!
That's all behind us now, Elaine.  And no matter what happens, I want you to know I've always loved you. McCROSKY (V.O.) Jesus, would someone answer me!!
I love you, Ted.
They smile at each other. McCROSKY (V.O.) What the hell's going on up there?!
Ted and Elaine still smile at each other.
All passengers look forward and smile.
All Controller's look down the line and smile.
Six soldiers on firing squad duty, ready to fire, turn, smile, and FIRE while they're smiling.
Ted grabs the radio.
(smiling lovingly) Ted, this reminds me of twenty years ago over Chicago.
Ted hits a switch.  The ship does a barrel roll.
All we see are feet sticking up from the seats.
(on radio) This is Mayflower One calling mission control.  Do you read me?  Over.
McCROSKY A man.  Now that's more like it. (continuing on radio) This is mission control.  Identify yourself and give me your position.  Over.
(on radio) The name's Ted Striker and I'm sitting down and facing the front.
McCROSKY (trying to place the name) Striker... Striker... Striker...
If you say so.
He slugs the female worker next to him. McCROSKY (remembering) Ted Striker!
McCROSKY Damn!  We've lost them again.
Could be those sunspots.
Could be your dishwashing detergent. McCROSKY Striker's the guy who flew that 736 into Chicago over 20 years ago without a crew. Would someone tell me what in sam hill he's doing up there?
(waving his hand in the air) Me!  Me!  Me!
They are swinging aluminum doors similar to restaurant kitchens and hospital operating rooms.  Kruger and the Commissioner enter through one door.
The boys downtown are taking the heat from the boys in Washington and the boys...
They PASS OUT OF FRAME.  A waiter with tray passes them a leaves through the swing doors.
Two surgeons in operating gowns and masks enter covered i food. We PICK UP Kruger and the Commissioner still walking and talking.
Bud, the President wants an explanation.
They approach McCrosky. McCROSKY Sorry to pull you out of bed at this hour, gentlemen.
Forget it.  I was reading.
I was reading too.
What's the story?
Some southern plantation owner falls in love with this poor...
I was asking McCrosky, Commissioner. McCROSKY He falls in love with this poor school teacher who...
A CONTROLLER interrupts them.
(to McCrosky) Sir, we've restored radio transmission. McCROSKY Good. (to Kruger) We keep losing their radio.
Give it to me straight, McCrosky -- what's it look like. McCROSKY It's green with numbers and lots of knobs.
Not the radio, the situation.  I want to know exactly what your people think.
PAN three Controllers at monitors.
(thinking) They're screwed.
(thinking) They're dead.
(thinking) Did I leave the iron on?

The ship lurches from side to side. Stella, covered in blood, kneels beside BILLY, a young ma bandaged head to toe, lying on a stretcher with lots of I bottles hanging around him.  A U.S. ARMY GENERAL stands n to him -- imagine General Patton.
General Walker is here, Billy.  He wants to talk to you.
Billy, if we get through this thing alive, I'd like you to get this letter to my mother.
He hands Billy a letter.
Elaine is monitoring various dials.  Ted is at controls a on the radio.

(on radio) An electrical fire in the core has played havoc with the ROK-4000 computer.  It's locked us on a direct line with the sun and there's no way we can go to manual. Captain Oveur already tried it and he's...
(from floor) Giants sixty... Rams... zip...
... become an intolerable bore.  The rest of the crew has been lost and we're out of coffee.  Also, we're starting to feel the sun's heat pretty bad.
Striker wipes his forehead.  Elaine holds a tan reflector to her face and turns to the sun.
Passengers sweat profusely. SFX:  JUNGLE SOUNDS. A MAN slaps a mosquito on the back of his neck. FOUR MEN sit nude to the waist, wrapped in towels as if i steam bath.
It's eight-thousand square feet with great parking and a twenty-year lease with option to buy.
You can't lose, Al.
He can lose.  I've seen it happen a thousand times.
It shoots towards sun.

McCrosky sits at a monitor, talks into a mike and looks d at a book.  Behind him two Controllers make a dope deal - baggie of grass for cash.  We only see their midsections hands. McCROSKY Striker, this is Jack McCrosky, chief controller.  I want you to listen to me and listen good.
The buyer checks out the baggie -- it's mostly twigs.  Th seller is trying to explain the situation with his hands. McCROSKY Twenty years ago I helped a young pilot through a storm over Chicago.
